sp.p: That's it I would have man, weele make them all drunke, they'le never leave us else, and still as it comes to a crowne, Ile steale downe and pay it in spite of their teeth, remember therefore that yee make them all drunke, but be sure you keepe me sober to pay the reckonings.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Oh Iarvis, Iarvis, how I long till I see thee.

div.stage: Enter Mol Bloodhound, and Sim, with a letter,

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: There wee must meet soone, and bee married to morrow morning, Sim, is't not a mad brother?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Yes, and I can tell you newes of a mad Lover.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: What is he in the name of Cupid?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Why one Master Randals, a Welchman, I have had such a fit with him, he sayes he was wisht to very wealthy Widdow, but of you he has heard much Histories, that he will marry you, though he never saw you, and that the parboyl'd Aetna of his bosome, might be quencht by the consequent pastime, in the prittish flames of his prittish blood, he salutes you with that love letter.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: This is a mad Lover indeede, prethee reade it.

sp.speaker: Sim,
sp.p: Mas, has writ it in Welch English, we had beene spoil'd else, for want of an interpreter, but thus he begins, Mistresse Maries.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: He makes two Maries serve one Mistresse?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Ever while you live, 'tis your first rule in Weleh Grammers, that her forsake Widdowes, and take Maids, was no creete wonder, for Sentlemen ever love the first cut.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: But not o'th Coxecombe, hee should have put in that.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: The Coxecombe followes by consequence, marke else. I Randall cracke, of Carmaerden, doe love thee Mary Ploodbounds, of Hounds-ditch, dwelling Aulgate, and Pishops gate, iust as betweene hawke and buzzard.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: Hee makes an indifferent wooing,

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: And that her loves Maryes so monstrous, yet never saw her, was because her heare her in all Societies so ferry fillanously commended, but specially before one Master pussie Constables of her Parish, who made her selfe halfe fox't by swearing by the Wines, that Maries woo'd be monstrous good Marriages for Randals.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Master busie it seemes was not idle.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: If Maries can love a Prittaine of the plood of Cadwalader, which Cadwalader, was Prutes great Grandfather. Randalls was come in proper persons, pring round sillings in her pockets, get fathers good will, and go to Surch a Sunday, with a whole dozen of Welch Harps before her, so her rest her constant Lovers, Randall William, ap Thomas, ap Tavy, ap Robert, ap Rice, ap Sheffery, Cracke.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Fie, what shall I doe with all them?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Why, he sayd, these all rest your constant Louers, whereof, for manners sake, hee puts himselfe in the first place; he will call here presently, will you answere him by Letter or word of mouth.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Troth, neither of either, so let him understand.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Will ye not answere the Love-sicke gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: If hee bee sicke with the loue of mee, prithee tell him, I cannot endure him, let him make a vertue of necessitie, and apply my hate for's health.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I, but Ile haue more care of the Gentleman I warrant you, if I doe not make my selfe merry, and startle your mid-night meeting, say Sim has no more wit then his Godfathers, and they were both Head-men of this Parish.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Farewell Widdowes prove, her sall no Randals haue,
Widdowes was ferry full of wiles,
Mary Ploodhounds now, Randals make a vow,
Was runne for Moll a couple of miles.

div.stage: Honest Simkins, what sayd Mariee to Randals Letters?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Y'are a mad man.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.l: Augh, her was very clad her was mad.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: The old man has money enough for her, and if you marry her, as if your proiect take, you may, sheele take you more then a man.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: More then mans, what the?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Trough cannot you tell that, this is the trueth on't, she wood be married to morrow, to one Ancient Yong a fellow she cannot endure, now she sayes, if you coo'd meete her privatly to night, betwen ten & eleven, iust at the great Crosse-way, by the Nags head Taverne at Leaden-hall.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Was high, high pumpe, there as her turne into Graces streete.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Theres the very place, now because you come the welcomest man in the world to hinder the match against her mind with the Ancient, there she will meete you, goe with you to your lodging, lie there all night, and bee married to you i'th morning at the Tower, as soon as you shall please.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: Becat her will goe and prepare Priests presently, looke yee Simkins, there is a great deale of round sillings for her, her was very lucky sillings, for came to Randalls shust for all the World as Fortune was come to Foole, tell Maryes, her will meete her, her warrant her, make many puppy Fooles of Ancients, and loue her very monstrously. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, so, so, this midnight match shall bee mine, shee told mee shee was to meete the Ancient there, Ile bee sure the Ancient shall meete him there, so I shall lye a bedde to laugh, to thinke if hee meete her there, how she will bee startled, and if the Ancient meete him there, how hee will bee cudgelled, beware your ribbs Master Randall. Exit.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p:
I wonder where this young rogue spends the day, I heare hee has receiued my hundred Marks, and my
aduantage with it and it may be, hee went home since I went out. Iaruis was with me but euen now, and bid mee watch, and narrowly, for feare of some of my Riuall spies: For I know shee has many wealthy Suitours, all loue money. This Iaruis is most neate in a loue businesse; and when we are married because many mouthes much meate, I will requite his curtesie, and turne him away; the Widdowe's all I looke for.— Nay, let her fling to see I haue her possessions, there's a Saw for't.
sp.l: There's thriving in Wiving: For when we burie
Wiues by halfe-dozens, the Money makes marrie.
Oh money, money, money, I will build thee
An Altar on my heart, and offer to thee
My morning longings, and my euening wishes,
And hadst thou life, kill thee with couetous kisses.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: But now and shee speake shee spoiles all, or if hee call her by my Mistris his name, hast thou no: trickes to enioyne them both to silence till they come sure.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Phaw, that's a stale one, she shall speake to him in her owne accent, hee shall call her by her owne name leauing out the Bawd, yet she shall violently beleeue he loues her, and hee shall confidently beleeue the same which hee requires, and she but presents. Enter Mistris Coote.
sp.l: Fall off, shee comes.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Iaruis.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Here I haue discouered him, 'tis he by his coughes, remember your instructions, & vse few words, for though till to night you knew it not, and will he married early in the morning, to preuent a Vintners Widdow, that layes clayme to him.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Iaruis.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Good old man, I know him by his tongue.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Is shee come? is shee come Iaruis?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Aske her if shee wood liue sir, shee walkes a loose yonder.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: We shall cozen all her woers.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p:
Nay, amongst all of you, weele cozen one great one, that had layd a pernitious plot this night, with a cluster
of his roaring friends to surprize her, carry her downe to the water side, pop her in at Puddle-dock, and carry her to Graues end in a payre of Oares.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: What, what is his name I prithee.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Hee's a Knight abounding in deedes of charity, his name Sir Nicholas Name.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: And wood he pop her in at Puddle-dock?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: And he cood but get her downe there.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: By my troath we shall pop him fairely, where is shee? where is shee?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Ha, doe you not perceiue a fellow walke vp and downe muffled yonder?

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: There is something walkes.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: That fellow has dogd vs all the way, and I feare all is frustrate.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Not I hope man.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: This tis to be in loue, if I doe not dwindle.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: I know him now.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Tis none of Sir Nicholas spies, is't?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: Hee serues him.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: He wonnot murder mee, will hee?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: He shall not touch you, onely I remember this after-noone, this Fellow by what he had gathered by caues dropping, or by frequent obseruation, ask'd me priuately if there were no meeting betwixt you and my Mistris to night in this place, for a Widdow hee said hee knew you were to meete.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Now I hansomly threw dust in's eyes, and yet kept the plot swift a foote too, I told him you were heere to meete a Widdow too, whom you long loued, but would not let her know't till this after-noone, naming to him one of my Aunts, a Widdow by Fleete-Ditch, her name is Mistris Gray, and she keepes diuers Gentlewomen lodgers.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Good agen.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: To turne the sent then, and to cheat Inquisition the more ingeniously.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: And to bob Sir Nicholas most neatly.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Bee sure all this night studably in the hearing of any that ye shall but suspect to be within hearing to call her nothing but Mistris Coote.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Or Widdow Coote.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Yes, you may put her in so, but bee sure you cohere in every particle, with the precedent Fallacie, as that you haue loved her long, tho till this day, and so as I did demonstrate.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: But how and she woo'd say she is not Widdow Come, and that she knowes no such woman, and so spoile all?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Trust that with her wit, and my instructions wee suspected a spie, and therefore she will change her voice.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Thou hast a delicate Mistris of her.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: One thing more, and yee meete presently, mine Aunt has had mine husbands, tell her youle hazard a limbe and make the tenth.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Prithee let me alone, and Sir Nicholas were here himselfe, he shoo'd sweare 'twere thine Aunt.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Goe forwards towards him, bee not too full of pratle, but make use of your instructions.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Who's there, Widdow Coote?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Master Bloodbound as I take it.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Shee changes her voice bravely, I must tell thee true Widdow, I have loved thee long time, looke how the Rogue lookes, but had never the wit to let thee know it till to day.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: So I was given to understand Sir.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: Is't not a foole finely?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Hansome by this hand.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: I like thy dwelling well upon the Fleete ditch.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: A pretty wholesome Ayre Sir, in the Summer time.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Who would thinke 'twere she Iarvis?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: I told ye she was tutor'd.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Ile home with her presently, some stayes up i'th darke.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Foole and he haue any priuate discourse with her, they discouer themselues one to another, and so spoile the plot, no trick, no by no meanes sir, to hazard your person with her, the bold roague may come vp close to discouer her to be my Mistresse, and recouer her with much danger to you.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Hee has got a dagger.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: And a sword sixe foote in length, I'le carry her home for you, therefore not a light be stirring; for I know your Riualls will watch your house, Sim shall shew vs the chamber, weele conduct her vp ith dark, shut the doore to her aboue, and presently come downe and let you in belowe.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: There was neuer such a Iaruis heard off, bid Sim to be carefull, by the same token, I told him he shood feed to morrow for all the weeke after: good night Widdow, Coote my man stayeth vp, we will bob Sir Nicholas brauely. Good night sweet widdow Coote. I doe but seeme to part, weele meete at home wench. — Exit.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Adieu my sweet deare heart.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Goe you with me, so, so, I will Cage this Cookow, and then for my young Madcap, if all hit right, this mornings mirth shall crowne the Craft o'th night, follow mee warily.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: I warrant thee Iaruis, let me alone to right my selfe into the garbe of a Lady: Oh strange to see how dreames fall by contraries, I shall bee coacht to morrow, and yet last night dream'd I was carted: prithee keepe a little state, goe Iaruis. Exit

sp.speaker: Randall.
sp.p: Was ferry exceeding darke, but here is high pumps, sure here is two coppie of crosse wayes, and there was the street where Grace dwells, one hundred pound in mornings in round shillings, and wife worth one thousand ere her goe to bed. Randalls fortunes comes tumbling in, like Lawyers Fees, huddle vpon huddle.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p:
Oh sweet Antient, keepe thy word, and winne my heart, They say, a Moone-shine night is good to runne
away with another mans wife, but I am sure a darke night is best to steale away my Fathers daughter.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.l: Mary.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Oh, are ye come Sir? there's a boxe of Land and livings, I know not what ye call it.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.l: Lands, and livings?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Nay, nay, and wee talke, we are undone, doe ye not see the Watch comming up Gracious-streete yonder, this Crosse way was the worst place wee could have met at, but that is yours, and I am yours, but good Sir doe not blame me, that I so suddenly yeelded to your love, alas you know what a match an't I should have to morrow else.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.l: Her meanes the scurvy Ancient.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: I'th morning wee shall bee Man and Wife, and then, alas I am undone, the Watch are hard upon us, got you backe through Cornehill, Ile runne round about the Change, by the Church corner: downe Cat-eaten streete, and meete you at Bartholomew Lane end. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: Cats streete was call her, sure Randalls was wrapt in mothers smocke. Exit.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Keepe streight towards Bishops-gate, I am deceived and I heard not somebody run that way.

div.stage: Enter Chamber-maid, Hugh with a Band boxe.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.p: Stay Sir, here's somebody come from Aldgate-ward?

sp.speaker: Mayd.
sp.p: Alas, I shall bee hang'd for staying so long for this Cuffe.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: Come before the Constable here.

sp.speaker: Mayd.
sp.p: Let the Constable come before mee and hee please.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: How, how, where ha you bin pray Dame, ha?

sp.speaker: Mayd
sp.p: For my Mistresse Ruffe, at her Sempstris Sir, she must needes use it to morrow, and that made mee stay till 'twas done.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Pray who's your Mistris, where dwell ye?

sp.speaker: Mayd.
sp.p: With one Mistris Wagge in Black-Fryers, next to the signe of the Feathers and the Foole sir.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Oh, I know her very well, make hast home, tis late. Come, come, let's backe to Gracechurch, all's well, all's well.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I scapt the Watch at Bishopsgate with ease, there is some body turning downe the Church corner towards the Exchange, it may be Mistris Mary.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: Antient.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Are yee heere againe, you haue nimbly followed me; what said the Watch to yee?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I past them easily, the gates are but now shut in.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: As wee goe, I'le tell you such a tale of a Welch wooer, and a lamentable Loue-letter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes, Sim told mee of such a Rat, and where hee lodges, I thought I should haue met him here.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Here, out vpon him:— But the Watches walke their station, and in few words is safety, I hope you will play faire, and lodge mee with the Mayd ye told me of.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: She stayes vp for vs Wench, in the word of a Gentleman, all shall be faire and ciuill.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: I beleeue you.

div.stage: Enter at seuerall doores Randalls and Mayd.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: Zounes was another Fyer Drake walke in Shange, weele run packe, mas Maryes haue saued her labours, and was come after Randalls, Maryes was Randall that loues her mightily Maryes.

sp.speaker: Mayd.
sp.l: Master Randall.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.l: How did Watch let her goe at Graces street?

sp.speaker: Mayd.
sp.l: They knew me, and let me passe.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p:
Well now, her vnderstands Maryes loues Randalls
so mighty deale.

sp.speaker: Mayd.
sp.l: If Iohn haue not told him, I'le be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: Maryes shall goe with Randalls to lodgings, and that her Father worke no diuorcements, hee will lye with her aule t'night, and marry her betimes next morning, meane time her will make Lands and Livings fast.

sp.speaker: Mayd.
sp.p: How Father? this is a mistake sure, and to fashion it fit for mine owne following, I will both question and answere in ambiguities, that if hee snap me any way, I may make my selfe good ith tother, and as hee shall discouer himselfe, I'le pursue the conceit accordingly: but will yee not deceiue mee, many mindes are many mens Almanacks, the dates of your desire's out, wee serue for nothing but to light Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.l: If Randall false to Maryes proue,
Then let not Maryes Randalls loue:
For Randalls was so true as Ioue,
And Maryes was her ioy.
If Randalls was not Pritaine borne,
Let Maryes Randalls prowe adorne.
And let her giue a foule great horne to Randalls,
Her will loue her cret deale of much her warrant her.

sp.speaker: Mayd.
sp.p: And 'tis but venturing a maydenhead, if the worst come to the worst, it may come backe with aduantage. Exit.

div.stage: Enter in her night-cloathes, as going to bed Widdow and Mayd.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Is not Mary come home yet?

sp.speaker: Mayd.
sp.l: No forsooth.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Tis a fine time of night, I shall thanke her for't, 'tis past eleuen I am sure. Fetch, the prayer-booke lyes within vpon my bed.

sp.speaker: Mayd.
sp.l: Yes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Widdow.
sp.p:
I wonder what this Gentleman shood bee
that catcht me so like Iarvis, hee saye hee has fitted old Bloodhound according to his qualitie— but I must not let him dally too long upon my daily company, Lust is a hand-woolfe, who with daily feeding, one time or other takes a suddaine start upon his benefactor.

sp.speaker: Mayd.
sp.l: Oh Mistresse, Mistresie.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: What's the matter wench?

sp.speaker: Mayd.
sp.l: A man, a man under your bed Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: A man, what man?

sp.speaker: Mayd:
sp.p: A neate man, a proper man, a welfavoured man, a hansome man.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Call up Iohn, where's Iarvis?

sp.speaker: Mayd.
sp.p: Alas, I had no power to speake, his very lookes are able to make a woman stand as still as a Millers horse when hees lading, o he comes, he comes. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: How came you hither Sir? how got you in?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: As Citizens wives doe into Maskes, whether I woo'd or no nay, nay, doe not doubt the discretion of my constitution: I have brought nere a groat in my bosome, and by this hand, I lay under thy bed, with a heart as honest, and a blood as cold, as had my sister lay near top— will ye have me yet?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: You are very rude, uncivill fellow.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Vnciuill, and lay so tame while you set up your foote upon the bed, to untie your shooe, such another word, I will uncivillize that injured civilitie which you so scurvily slander, and reward you with an undecencie proportionable to your understandings, will yee have mee, will you marry mee?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You, why tomorrow morning I am to be married to your Father.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: What, to sixtie, and I know not how many, that will lie by your side, and divide the houres with coughes, as Cockes doe the night by instinct of Nature.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: And provide for his familie all day.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: And onely wish well to a fayre wife all night.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: And keepe's credite all day in all companies.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: And discredit himselfe al night in your company.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Fie, fie, pray quite my house Sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Yours, 'tis my house.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Your house, since when?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Even since I was begotten, I was borne too't, I must have thee, and I will have thee, and this house is mine, and none of thine.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Oh Mistris, the saddest Accident i'th streete yonder.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: What Accident prithee?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: You must pardon my boldnesse, into your bedde-Chamber, there is a Gentleman slaine in a fraye at the doore yonder, and the people wonnot bee perswaded, but that hee that did it, tooke this house, there is the Constable, Church-wardens, and all the Head-men of the Parish, be now searching, and they say they will come up hither to your bed chamber, but they'le find him, Ile keepe them downe as long as I can, I can doe no more then I can. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Are not you the murderer Sir?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I ha beene under thy bedde by this hand this three houres.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pray get you downe then, they will all come up, and find you here and all, and what will the Parish thinke then? pray get you downe.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: No, no, no; I will not goe downe now I thinke on't. makes himselfe vnready.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why, what doe you meane, you will not bee so uncivill to unbrace you here?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: By these Buckles I will, and what they will thinke on't—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Alas, you will undoe me.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: No, no, I will undoe my selfe looke ye.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Good Sir, I will off with my doublet to my very shirt.

sp.speaker: Iarvis.
sp.p: Pray sir have more care of a Womans reputation.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Have a care on't thy selfe Woman, and marry mee then.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Shood they come up and see this: what coo'd they thinke, but that some foule uncivill Act of shame had this night stain'd my house, and as good marry him as my name lost for ever.

sp.speaker: Alexand.
sp.p: Will you have mee afore tother sleeve goes off?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Doe, hang your selfe, I will not have you— looke, looke, if he have not pul'd it off quite, why you wonnot pull off your bootes too will you?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Breeches and all by this flesh.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What, and stand naked in a Widdowes Chamber.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: As naked as Grantham steeple, or the Strand May-pole by this spurre, and what your grave Parishioners will thinke on't?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: Gentlemen pray keepe downe.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Alas, they are at the staires foote, for Heavens sake Sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Will you have me?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: What shall I doe? no.

sp.speaker: Alex,
sp.p: This is the last time of asking, they come up, and downe goe my breeches, will you have me?

sp.speaker: Widdow.
sp.l: I, I, I, alas, and your breeches go downe
I am undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Why then kisse mee upon't, and yet there's no cracking your credite, Iarvis is come in, Iarvis.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: I have kept my promise Sir, y'are catcht the olde one.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: How catcht, is there no body below then?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: No body but Iohn, for sooth, recovering a Tobacco snuffe, that departed before supper.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: And did you promise this Sir?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: A woman cannot have a hansomer cloud, then a haire-brain'd Husband: I will be your Cooze, hee shall bee my Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I love ye for your Art.

sp.speaker: Iarvis.
sp.p: Come, Come, put on Sir, I have acquainted yee both with your Fathers intended marriage, i'th morning you shall certifie him very earlie by Letter, the qualitie of your fortunes, and returne to your obedience, and that you and your wife, still concealing the parties, will Attend him to Church, Iohn and Ile bee there earely, as commanded by my Mistresse, to discharge our attendance: about goes the plot, out comes the proiect, and these's a wedding dinner drest to your hands.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: As pat as a fat Heire to a leane Sharke, wee shall hunger for't, honest Iarvis, I am thy bed-fellow to night, and to morrow thy Master.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Y'are a fine man to use a woman thus?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Pish, Come, come, fine men must use fine Women thus, tis fit, plaine trueth takes Maids, Widdowes, are wonne with wit.

sp.speaker: Iarvis.
sp.p: You shall weare hornes with wisedome, that is in your pocket.

div.head: Actus 5. Scaena. 1.
div.stage: Enter Sim, and Iohn, passing over with a Bason of Rosemary, and a great Flaggon with Wine.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Come Iohn, carry your hand steddily, the guesse droppe in a pace, doe not let your wine drop on't.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Tis as I told thee, Master Alexander, thy Mistresse
eldest sonne will be here.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Rose, I pray burne some pitch i'th Parlour, 'tis good against ill ayres, Master Alexander will be here.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: I am up before yee sonne Earelacke, will Ancient Young bee here with a rich Wife too? thy Mistresse is not stirring yet sirrah, Ile hold my life the Baggage slipe to thy Mistresse, there they have e'ne lockt the doore to them, and are tricking up one another: oh these women! but this Rogue Tim, hee lay out to night too, he received my hundred Marke, and I feare is murdered: Trusse, Trusse, good Iarvis.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: He has bin a wooing Sir, and has fetcht over the delicat'st young Virgin, her Father died but a weeke since, and left her to her marriage, five thousand pound in money, and a parcel of Land, worth three hundred Perannum.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Nay, nay, 'tis like, the boy had ever a captivating tongue to take a woman— o excellent money, excellent money, Mistresse of my devotions, as if my Widdowes estate is little lesse too, and then Sander, he has got a monied woman too, there will be a bulke of money, Sim is puling sir, I may tell thee, one that by natures course, cannot live long: tother, a Mid-night sunset cuts off, then have I a tricke to cozen both their Widdowes, and make all mine, ô Iarvis, what a monied generation shall I then get upon thy Mistresse?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: A very vertuous brood.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Has't done?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: I have done Sir.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Ile in and get some musicke for thy Mistresse, to quicken her this morning, and then to Church in earnest, 'tis done, where is Sir Nicholas Nemo and his words that watch so for her? Ha, ha, ha, al's mixt with honey, I have mirth, a sweete young Widdow and her money, ô that sweete Saint, cal'd money.

div.stage: Enter Alexander, Widdow, Antient, Moll and Sim.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ioy I, and a 100 pound a yeere in a black boxe to the bargaine giuen away i'th darke last night, to we know not who, and to be heard of wee know not when. Sfoote and this be ioy, wood we had a handfull, some slice of sorrow to season it.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: By this light 'twas strange.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Beleeue me Sir, I thought I had giuen it you, he that tooke it call'd me by my name.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Did he speake Welch or English?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Alas, I know not, I enioyned him silence seeing the Watch comming, who parted vs.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: If this were not Master Randalls of Randall Hall that I told yee of, I'le be fleaed.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Be maskt, and with-draw a while, heere comes our Dad.

div.stage: Enter Bloodhound, Sir Marmaduke Many minds, Sir Ianus Ambodexter, and Master Busie.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Why Master Busie, asleepe as thou standst man?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Some horse taught him that 'tis worth god a mercie.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I watch all night, I protest Sir the Counters pray for me, I send all in Cut and long taile.

sp.speaker: Sir Marma.
sp.l: What, what?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I sent twelue Gentlewomen, our owne neighbours last night, for being so late but at a womans labour.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Alas Sir, a woman in that kind you know must ha' helpe.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What's that to me? I am to take no notice of that, they might haue let her alone till morning, or shee might haue cryed out some other time.

sp.speaker: Sir Mar.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Master Busie knowes his place I warrant yee.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Sonne Alexander welcome, and Antient Young to, I haue heard all.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: You must pardon the meritable rudenesse of the Gentlewomen Sir, in not vnmasking, they entreated mee to informe you: there are some ith house to whom they wood by no meanes be layd open.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: They are witty, they are witty.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: But for my selfe, I am now your most obedient vertuous Alexander.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Obedience, hang her vertue, let her starue; has she money? hath she money?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Two Chests of siluer, and two Vtropian Trunks, full of gold and Iewels.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: They are all Alexanders women, doe ye marke?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Alexander was the Conquerour Sir.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Come, come, weele to Church presently: Prithee Iaruis whilst the Musicke playes iust vpon the delicious close, vsher in the Brides, the Widdow, and my Moll.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I tell yee true Gallants, I haue seene neither of them to day. Shall I giue him the lye?

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: They are both lockt vp ifaith, trimming of one another. Oh these women, they are so secret in their businesse, they will make very Coxcombs of vs men, and doo't at pleasure to, 'tis well said friends, play, play, where's Sim?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How he bestirres him.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Yes, he will sweat by and by.

sp.speaker: Sim
sp.l: Here is the signe of Sim Sir.

sp.speaker: Blood
sp.l: Haue the guests Rosemary without?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: They haue Rose the Cooke-mayd without, but they say you haue Mistris Mary within.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Well said Rascall.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Marie's aboue good-man Blockhead. Call my sonne Earelack, bid him for shame make hast.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: He shall make hast for shame.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: I am so busied, you must beare with me Gentlemen, they leaue it all to me here.

sp.speaker: Coast.
sp.p: But I will goe charge some of the inferiour guesse in the Kings name to fill some wine.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: No, no, good Master Busie, wee will first vsher the brides.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Oh Gentlemen, where are you? where are you?
Where are you Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Where's Moll Sim, the Widdow Sim, the dainty Widdow?

sp.speaker: Sim
sp.p: There is no Moll, there is no dainty young Widdow, but a damnable Bawd we found a bed with a face like an Apple halfe rosted.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Why Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now it workes.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Iaruis y'are a Roague, a Cut-purse Iaruis, runne Sim, call my sonne Earelack, hee shall put her into the Spirituall Court for this.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Nay, has put her in there already, for wee found him a bed with her.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Possible.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Ha Boyes, the Informer and the Bawd, the Bawd and the Informer haue got a deuill betwixt them Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Nay Sir, the iest was, that they should fall asleepe together, and forget themselues, for very louingly wee found them together, like the Iemini, or the two Winter mornings met together: Looke, looke, looke where they come Sir, and Iaruis betweene them, iust like the picture of knauery, betwixt fraud and leachery.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Tim is a puling Sirrah, I may tell it thee, a midnight surfet too may cut off Sander, I'le cozen their Wiues, make all mine owne, and then, Oh Iaruis what a moneyed generation shall I get, vpon this widdow Coote that hath two teeth.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Did wee bring you to Musick with a mischiefe Earlack? thou art a Goat, thou hast abus'd the best bed in my house, I'le set a Sumner vpon thee.

sp.speaker: Earla.
sp.p: Bloodhound, thou art a Vsurer, and takest forty in the hundred, Ile informe against thee.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Are you a Bawd huswife, ha?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Alas Sir, I was meerely enuied, betray'd by Iaruis, but as I haue beene Bawd to the flesh, you haue beene Bawd to your money; so set the Hare Pye against the Goose giblets, and you and I are as daintily matcht as can be sir.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Sim, runne to the widdow Wagges, tell her wee are both abus'd, this Iaruis is a Jugler, say.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I can saue Sim that labour Sir, I assure you the widdow is married to your sonne Alexander, and as a confirmation she is come her selfe to witnesse it. Discouers.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Your faire young daughter is wife to this Antient, who is come likewise to witnesse it.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: The plaine truth is Master Bloodhound, I would entreate you to keepe the kennell, the younger dogge being of the better sent, has borne the game before yee.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: We haue clapt hands on't Sir, and the Priest that shood haue married you to her, is to marry her to me, so sister, talke for your selfe.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Ha braue tricks and conceits, can yee dance Master Earelack?

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Ha, ha: the old man's a little mad: but thou art not married Moll?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Yes indeed Sir, and will lye with this Gentleman soone at night: doe you thinke I wood chew Ramme mutton, when I might swallow Venison, that's none of Venus documents Monsieur Dottevill?

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Pox of that Venus, shee is a Whore I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: And were not you the tother Iugler with Iaruis in this, hey passe and repasse.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Good Sir be satisfied, the Widdow and my sister sung both one song, and what was't, but Crabbed age and youth cannot liue together. Now wee perswaded them, and
they coo'd not live together, they wood never indure to lie together, this consequently descended, there was the Antecedent, wee clapt hands, sealed lippes, and so fell unto the relative,

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: This was your bargaine upon the Exchange Sir, and because you have ever beene addicted to old proverbs, and pithy Sawes, pray let mee seale up the mistake with one that will appeare very seasonably.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: And I pray let's heare it sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: You, a new fangled fowler, came to shew your Art i'th darke, but take this trueth, you catcht in trueth a Cookow for't. Enter Tim.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Heyday, wee are cheated by the rule ifaith, now sirrah, they say you are to be married too.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Yes indeed Father, I am going to the busines, and Gentlemen all, I am come whether you will or no, to inuite ye all to my marriage, to this Gentlewoman, who though a good face need no Maske; shee's maskt to make a man thinke she has a scurvy face, when I know she has a good face, this is Sacke to them and out of their Element.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: But sirrah, setting aside marriages, where's my hundred Marke you went to receive?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Hum, upon such a match of mine, talke of a hundred Marke, this is to drinke ignoble sonne shillings beere, a hundred Marke, why your Lawyer there can cleere such a trifle in a Tearme, and his Clients ne're the better.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Such a match, I pray discover her, what is she?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: What is shee, heere's my Brother knowes what shee is well enough, come hither Dab, and bee knowne unto you, her name is Lindabrades, descended from the Emperour Tribatio of Greece, and halfe Neece, some sixe and fiftie descents to most unvanquisht Claridiana.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Who's this? poxe on't, what vnmasks her .makes that Bawd yonder?

sp.speaker: Bussy.
sp.p: I am very much deceiued, and I did not send this Gentlewoman very drunke tother night to'th Counter.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I tell thee pratling Constable, 'tis a lye, Lindabrades a Drunkard?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Harke ye brother, where lyes her living?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Where, why in Greece.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: In grease.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: She lookes as if she had sold Kitchinstuffe.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: This is a common whore, and you a cheated Coxcombe, come hither, you rotten Hospitall, hung round with greasie Sattin, doe not you know this Vermine?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: I winckt at ye Sue, and ye coo'd have seene me, there's one Iaruis, a rope on him has juggled mee into the sudds too.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Now I know her name too, doe not you passe under the name of Sue shortheeles, minion?

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.p: Goe looke Master little wit, will not any woman thrust her selfe upon a good fortune, when tis offered her?

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Sir Marmaduke, you are a Iustice of peace; I charge ye in the Kings name, you and Master Ambodexter, to assist me with the Whore and the Bawd, to Bridewell.

sp.speaker: Sir Mar.
sp.p: By my troth and we will, by that time we shal have an excellent stomacke by that time dinners ready.

sp.speaker: Ambodex.
sp.l: I, I, away with them, away with them.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Oh this Rogue Iarvis.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Now, now, you looke like a melancholly dog, that had lost his dinner, where's my hundred Markes now you Coxecombe?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Truely father, I have payd some sixeteene reckonings, since I saw you, I was never sober since you sent mee to the Devill yesterday, and for the rest of your money, I sent it to one Captaine Carvegut, he swore to me his Father was my Lord Maiors Cooke, and that by Easter next, you should have the principall, and egges for the use indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Blood
sp.p: Oh Rogue, Rogue, I shall have egges for my money, I must hang my selfe.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Not afore dinner pray Sir, the Pyes are almost bak't. Enter Rand.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: And Maryes now was won, and all her pusinesse done, and Randalls now was runne, her haue made all sure I her warant her.

sp.speaker: Alexand.
sp.p:
Looke, looke, yonder's the conceit, the
mistake happened upon last night.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And the very boxe at's girdle.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: Cot plesse her Father Ploodhounds, Randals have rob'd Ancients her warrant her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir 'tis knowne how you came by that boxe.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: Augh was her so, will heare an Noble Prittaine, how her gull an English Flag?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And you ought to crye.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: Oh noble Randalls, as her meete by Nags-head with Mayres Plood, prave.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Here's another mad-man.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Hearke in your eare, you must deliver that boxe to mee.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: Hearke in her tother eare, her will not deliver her, and her were nine and forty Ancients, and five and fourescore Flaggs.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Let my foe write mine Epitaph, and if I teare not my birth-right from thy bosome?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Gentlemen, there's Alegant i'th house, pray set no more abroach.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: Nay let her come with her packe of needles, Randalls can poxe and bob, as well as her, her warrant her.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: What boxe is that? I shoo'd know that boxe.

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.l: I will resolve ye sir, keepe them asunder.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You will restore that boxe?

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: Her will not restore her, 'twas Mary Ploodhounds gave her the box, Randals have married Mary Ploodhounds and gul'd Ancients, marke her now.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Marke him good Sir, me thinkes he sayes hee has married Mary Bloodhound.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Hang him, hee's mad!

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: Zoun's, make Tog of Randalls? come out here Maries.
Looke here was Mary Ploodhounds. Enter Maid & Hugh. now, I pray tumble downe of her Mary-pones, and aske her father plessing?

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.l: This, why this is your Maid Widdow,

sp.speaker: Eare.
sp.l: This is Mary the Widdowes Maid man.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: And here is Mary Ploodhound, my chollericke shredde of Cadwallader, married to this Gentleman, who has a hundred a yeere dangling at your girdle there.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I pray Mistresse are you married to this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: By sixe i'th morning forsooth, hee tooke mee for Mary Ploodhound, having it seemes, never seene any on's before, and I being something amorously affected, as they say to his Welch ditties, answered to her name, lay with him all night, and married him this morning, so that as he tooke me for her, I tooke him as he was forsooth.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Shee meanes for a foole, I am faine to answere for you.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, Cupid this twentie foure houres has done nothing but cut crosse capers.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Doe ye heare, sir Bartholomew Bayard, that leape before ye looke, it will hansomly become you, to restore the Boxe to that Gentleman, and the Magnitude of your desiree, upon this daintie, that is so amorouslie taken with your ditties.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.l: Her waile in woe, her plunge in paine.
sp.p: And yet becat her doe not neither, Randalls will prove her selfe Prittaines borne, and because her understands Ancients was prave fellowes, and great Travailers, there is her boxe for her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I thanke yee.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: And because was no remedies, before her aule, here will Randals embrace Maries, and take a pusse— kisses.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: Save ye gallants, doe ye want any guesse?
Call me thy Coz, and carrie it hansomelie.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Who have we here trow?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Do'st thou know the Gentleman that whisper'd to thee?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh wondrous well, hee bid mee call him Coz, and carrie it hansomely.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: Widdow, wood I were off againe.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Know all, this Gentleman has to obtaine his Lust, and loose desires, seru'd me this seven moneths, under the shape and name of Iarvis.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Possible?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Looke well, doe ye not know him?

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: The very face of Iarvis.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I truely Father, and he were any thing like him,
I would sweare 'twere he.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: I must cast my skinne; and am catcht— why Coz.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Come y'are cozened,
And with a Noble craft, he tempted mee
In mine owne house, and I bid him keep's disguise
But till this morning and he shoo'd perceive,
I loved him truely, intending here before ye,
To let him know't, especially i'th presence
Of you Sir, that intend me for your Wife.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What shoo'd this meane?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Some witty tricke I warrant thee, prithee dispatch him presently, that we were at Church.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: First, then know ye for trueth sir, I meane never to marry.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: How Woman?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: She has dispatcht you Sir.

sp.speaker: Wid:
sp.p: And for a trueth sir, know you, I never meane to bee your Whore.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: This is strange.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: But true, as shee whose chast immaculate soule,
Retaines the Noble stampe of her integritie,
With an undefac't perfection— perchance as these
Nay Common Fame, hath scattered you, conceive me,
Because pale jealousie (Cupids angry Foole)
Was frequent lodger at that signe of Folly;
My husbands soone suspitious heart, that I
In a close clouded loosenesse, shoo'd expose him
To that desperate distraction of his fortunes,
That sent him to the Sea, to nourish her,
With your vaine hope, that the Fame of frequent suitors,
Was but a Maske of loose scapes, like men at Lotteries:
You thought to put in for one Sir, but beleeve me,
You have drawne a blanke.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.l: Beca● her looke ferry blacke indeed,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Oh my beloved husband,
However in thy life, thy jealousie
Sent thee so farre to finde death, I will bee
I will be married to nothing but thy memory.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: But shall the pyes be spoyl'd then?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: Let her alone, if her husband doe not know this.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Her Husband I told you was a madman.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why her Husbands dead sir.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: He is not dead Sir, hee had it spread a purpose, he is in England, and in your house, and looke: doe ye not see him?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Where, where?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: Here, here hee is that hath found rash iealousie,
Loues ioyes, and a wife whose discreet carriage
Can intimate to all men a faire freedome.
And to one be faithfull, such a wife I proue,
Her husbands glory worth a wealthy Loue.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: You are welcome to my soule Sir.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: By my troth Master Wag this was a waggs trick indeede, but I knew I know yee, I remembred you a moneth agoe, but that I had forgotten where I saw you.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I knew you were a crafty Merchant, you helpt my Master to such bargaines vpon the Exchange last night: here has beene the merriest morning after it.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: My Pitchers broke iust at the Well head, but giue me leaue to tell you Sir, that you haue a noble Wife, and indeed such a one as wood worthily feast the very discretion of a wise mans desire, her wit ingeniously waytes vpon her vertue, and her vertue aduisedly giues freedome to her wit, but because my marriage shall seriously proceede, I wed my selfe Sir to Obedience, and filiall regularity, and vow to redeeme in the duty of a sonne, the affection of a father.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: Becat was as well spoke as Randall her selfe cood talke.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: All is forgotten now my best sonne Alexander, and that my wedding want no good company, I inuite you all.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: Come my deseruing Wife,
Wisedome this day remarries vs. And Gentlemen
From all our errours wee'le extract this truth,
Where vitious ends prepose, they stand on wheeles,
And the least turne of chance throwes vp their heeles:
But vertues Louers euer greene doe last,
Like Lawrell which no lightening can blast.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-digit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a keyword in context.
